channel.title: Hugo on Your Website Name
channel.description: Recent content in Hugo on Your Website Name

item.title: A Static Website Generator Example: Hugo
item.description: The last section should have given you a good idea of what a static website generator is. In fact, the directory structure and page creation methods we looked at were that of Hugo.

item.title: Add your content to the website
item.description: The main steps for creating your own website are as follows: Download Git Bash, Hugo and a text editor Setup Github Download the template files Preview the site Modify Basic Settings Check site and Upload to github Buy the domain and setup godaddy Connect github and Godaddy Plan your website Add your own content

item.title: Assembling a website: Putting it all together
item.description: From the perspective of the static generator there are the following stages in assembling a website. Stage 1: Load Site level configuration Load all the site level configuration defaults from the template Load all the site level configuration specified as markup (json, yaml or toml) that are input by the user overriding template defaults if necessary This is done through standard markup parsers available in the templating engine of the static website generator Stage 2: Create html for each content page in the content directory Load page level configuration by parsing the input markup (json, yaml or toml) Load page level content into memory by parsing the markdown into html.

item.title: Config.toml settings
item.description: The config.toml file contains most of the site settings. It is found directly in the main website folder. The following settings need to be changed in the file:

item.title: Connect github and Godaddy: the website goes live
item.description: The main steps for creating your own website are as follows: Download Git Bash, Hugo and a text editor Setup Github Download the template files Preview the site Modify Basic Settings Check site and Upload to github Buy the domain and setup godaddy Connect github and Godaddy Plan your website Add your own content

item.title: Contact Page Settings
item.description: The settings for the contact page http://www.your-domain.com/contact are contained in the contact.md file which is in the content folder. You can view the sample page in the demo site

item.title: Contact Success Page Settings
item.description: The settings for the contact page http://www.your-domain.com/contact_success/ are contained in the contact_success.md file which is in the content folder. You can view the sample page in the demo site

item.title: Download Git Bash, Hugo and a text editor
item.description: The following are going to be needed for creating your own site: Git Bash Hugo Text Editor Get git bash Go to Git Download Website At the top, you would find a few operating systems.

item.title: Download the template files
item.description: Open a command prompt create (mkdir) a folder where you want to keep your website files. For example, type mkdir c:\users\yourname\website. Note that you need to use forward slash if working in mac or linux environments.

item.title: Front Page Settings
item.description: The front page settings are contained in the _index.md file which is in the content folder. It contains most of the settings needed to be changed in the front page.

item.title: Get Github login and setup Github
item.description: As described here, a version control system (or VCS) is a system that records changes to a file or set of files over time so that you can recall specific versions later.

item.title: Implement your own static website with Godaddy and github in 10 easy steps
item.description: The main steps for creating your own website are as follows: Download Git Bash, Hugo and a text editor Setup Github Download the template files Preview the site Modify Basic Settings Check site and Upload to github Buy the domain and setup godaddy Connect github and Godaddy Plan your website Add your own content

item.title: Introduction to Static Sites with Hugo
item.description: This document is aimed at someone who has not built a website before, so if this is too simple, then bear with me, or skim through this section.

item.title: Modify Settings and site configurations
item.description: At this stage, you will want to modify all the settings like the site author name, website name, etc on the site to be your own.

item.title: Plan your website and contents
item.description: The main steps for creating your own website are as follows: Download Git Bash, Hugo and a text editor Setup Github Download the template files Preview the site Modify Basic Settings Check site and Upload to github Buy the domain and setup godaddy Connect github and Godaddy Plan your website Add your own content

item.title: Popup Success Page Settings
item.description: The settings for the popup success page http://www.your-domain.com/popup_success/ are contained in the popup_success.md file which is in the content folder. You can view the sample page in the demo site

item.title: Popup Success Page Settings
item.description: The privacy policy is simply a text file stored at privacy.md file which is in the content folder. The privacy policy will be displayed in http://www.

item.title: Retrieving a Webpage from the internet
item.description: what happens between you typing an address into your browser and the browser displaying the website? This forms the crux of what is the internet, or how something that exists remotely is displayed on your browser.

item.title: Setup local server and preview the site
item.description: Check whether the website works as is. For this you need to locally create a hugo server. Thankfully, this is as simple as writing a simple command on your terminal/bash.

item.title: Static Website Generators
item.description: In this section we get into the details of how a static website generator works. On one side there is a user (website creator) writing content that they want displayed.

item.title: Static Websites: Implications and Constraints
item.description: In the section Parts of a webpage we mentioned how a site can be made dynamic by adding javascript on the client side. From the last section we understood a site can be statically served or dynamically served on the server side.

item.title: Terms of Service Page
item.description: The privacy policy is simply a text file stored at termsservice.md file which is in the content folder. The terms of service will be displayed at http://www.

item.title: The parts of a regular webpage - HTML, CSS and Javascript
item.description: There are three basic parts to every website as you see it on your browser. The content, the styling and the logic. These are described by three parts, html, css and javascript.

item.title: Website Templates and the need for them
item.description: When you open a Word document to write something, you just open it and start writing. There is no friction between you thinking a thought and getting it in a computer readable format.
